Name: Peace operations
Short description: Deployment of military and/or civilian personnel to a conflict zone to promote peace
Description_tool: Peace operations are composed of “military and/or civilian personnel deployed by one or more third-party states, frequently but not necessarily under the auspices of a global or regional organization” (Mullenbach 2005, p. 529). The mandates and composition of peace operations can vary widely, from civilian observer missions to missions authorized to use military force to enforce the peace. Common goals include mitigating hostilities, restoring state authority, preventing recurrence of civil war, and/or achieving humanitarian goals, including the protection of civilians.
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) protecting vulnerable civilian populations
Theory of change: If peace operations help prevent the outbreak or recurrence of armed conflict, they would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities. In addition, if peace operations provide direct physical protection to civilian populations; defeat, detain, or degrade the capacity of atrocity perpetrators; and/or shift armed actors’ calculations of the costs and benefits of targeting civilians (e.g., by publicizing violations), they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Mediation
Short description: A non-legal conflict management process facilitated by an external actor
Description_tool: Mediation is “a process of conflict management where disputants seek the assistance of, or accept an offer of help from, an individual, group, state or organization to settle their conflict or resolve their differences without resorting to physical force or invoking the authority of law” (Bercovitch et al. 1991, p. 8).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Theory of change: If mediation helps prevent or end an armed conflict, it would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities because armed conflict is the strongest risk factor for mass atrocities (Bellamy 2011; Straus 2016).
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Prosecutions
Short description: Legal proceedings against suspected perpetrators of mass atrocities
Description_tool: Prosecutions of atrocity crimes are attempts to hold individuals criminally accountable for mass atrocities through national courts, the International Criminal Court, international tribunals, hybrid courts, or universal jurisdiction. This review is limited to analyses of the effects of actions to advance cases through courts, such as the referral of a case to a court, the opening of an investigation, indictments, arrest warrants, trials, and sentencing.
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Theory of change: If prosecutions increase the expected costs to individuals of committing atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if prosecutions satisfy the desire for justice for past atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities that might be committed to exact revenge on perpetrator groups. If prosecutions help remove individual perpetrators from positions of power or influence, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by facilitating a transition to a less atrocity-prone political leadership.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Support to non-state armed groups
Short description: Aid provided by a foreign state to a rebel group
Description_tool: Support to non-state armed groups is assistance--including “the provision of weapons, funds, logistics, military training and access to intelligence and sanctuaries" (Karlen 2017, p. 16)--provided by a foreign state to a non-state armed group (often referred to as a rebel group). This review does not include analyses of direct military intervention in support of a non-state armed group.
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations, and (4) facilitating a political transition.
Theory of change: If support to a non-state armed group enables the group to provide physical protection to civilian populations, to increase costs to other armed actors of committing atrocities (e.g., by attacking them in response to atrocities), or to destroy or degrade other groups’ capacities to commit atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if support to a non-state armed group enables it to defeat an abusive government and facilitate a political transition, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Targeted sanctions
Short description: Coercive measures that target the assets or activities of individuals or corporations
Description_tool: Targeted sanctions are “coercive economic measures taken against a target to bring about a change in behavior.” Targeted sanctions, which aim at specific individuals or entities, include “blocking of foreign assets under U.S. jurisdiction [and] prohibition on economic transactions [with sanctions targets] that involve U.S. citizens or businesses” (CRS 2021, p. 1). (Note that some studies reviewed consider arms embargoes as a type of targeted sanction. The Simon-Skjodt Center also reviewed evidence on arms embargoes separately due to the depth of research on the use and effects of this tool specifically.)
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, and (3) facilitating a leadership or political transition
Theory of change: If targeted sanctions raise the individual costs on the commission of atrocities, they will reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. These costs can be material (e.g., by freezing or seizing assets), reputational, or political. In addition, if targeted sanctions degrade perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities by denying them or raising the costs of acquiring critical means, such as funds, arms, and other enabling technological goods, they will reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities (Krain 2017; Lopez 2015).
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Naming and shaming
Short description: Public condemnation of perpetrators of mass atrocities
Description_tool: Naming and shaming is the publicizing of “rights-based violations and their perpetrators (naming) and bring[ing] more pressure to bear on perpetrators of rights violations to change their behavior (shaming)” (Krain 2012, p. 575; Keck and Sikkink 1998).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, or (2) facilitating a political transition
Theory of change: If naming and shaming imposes reputational costs on perpetrators and/or increases the expected future costs of committing atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities (Krain 2012; DeMeritt 2012). If naming and shaming imposes reputational and political costs that encourage perpetrators to consider exiting their positions of power, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by helping facilitate a political transition.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Arms embargoes
Description_tool: Arms embargoes prohibit arms transfers to a whole country (“blanket arms embargoes”), specific areas or forces within a country (“selective arms embargoes”), or individuals or groups regardless of location (“global arms embargoes”). Arms embargoes can target one or all sides of a conflict (“partial” and “impartial” arms embargoes, respectively) (SIPR 2007, pp. 2-3).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities
Theory of change: If arms embargoes deny potential perpetrators access to arms or raise the costs of acquiring arms, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by constraining their capacity for violence. If arms embargoes increase the expected cost of committing mass atrocities, potential perpetrators would be more likely to choose alternative options (Brubaker and Dorfler 2017, pp. 2, 8).
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Military intervention
Short description: Introduction of foreign military forces into a conflict
Description_tool: Military intervention is “the deliberate act of a nation or group of nations to introduce its military forces into the course of an existing controversy” (Department of Defense 2010, p. 153). Military intervention can include limited operations, such as ones focused on securing access routes or borders or enforcing no-fly zones, and more extensive operations, such as ones focused on defeating armed groups and establishing security across a country (Waxman 2009; Seybolt 2008).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations, and (4) facilitating a political transition.
Theory of change: If military intervention provides physical protection to civilian populations, increases costs to other armed actors of committing atrocities (e.g., by attacking them in response to atrocities), or destroys or degrades other groups’ capacity to commit atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities (Waxman 2009, pp. 6-7). In addition, if military intervention defeats an abusive government and facilitates a political transition, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Comprehensive economic sanctions
Short description: Coercive measures that target the economic capacity of a state
Description_tool: Comprehensive economic sanctions are “coercive economic measures taken against a target to bring about a change in behavior” (CRS 2021, p. 1). Comprehensive sanctions “block the government and include broad-based trade restrictions” (Treasury OFAC).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities
Theory of change: If comprehensive economic sanctions raise the costs on the commission of atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. These costs can be material (e.g., by increasing the relative economic strength of the opposition), reputational, or political (e.g., by contributing to social upheaval) (Wood 2008, p. 491). In addition, if comprehensive economic sanctions degrade perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities by denying them or raising the costs of acquiring critical means, such as funds, arms, and other enabling technological goods, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Official amnesties
Short description: The official barring of legal proceedings against certain individuals or groups
Description_tool: An official amnesty is “an official legislative or executive act whereby criminal investigation or prosecution of an individual, a group or class of persons and/or certain offences is prospectively or retroactively barred, and any penalties cancelled” (ICRC 2017, p. 1).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) facilitating a political transition.
Theory of change: If official amnesties increase the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, including by encouraging abusive leaders to give up power, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Diplomatic sanctions
Short description: Severing or downgrading diplomatic relations to signal disapproval
Description_tool: Diplomatic sanctions include “severing formal diplomatic ties with a country or significantly downgrading ties from the normal level of diplomatic activity for foreign policy purposes” (Maller 2009, p. 512). Diplomatic sanctions may specifically entail not recognizing a regime in public statements, withdrawing staff from or closing an embassy, “restrictions on travel for specific leaders” (MacGregor and Bowles 2012, p. 445), and “suspension of membership or expulsion from international or regional bodies” (ICISS 2001, p. 31). Diplomatic sanctions are intended to “signal disapproval of the target regime's behaviour, and also to signal the possibility of subsequent punitive measures should that behaviour not change” (Krain 2014, p. 27).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (4) facilitating a political transition.
Theory of change: If diplomatic sanctions impose reputational costs on potential perpetrators and/or increase their expectation that external actors will impose other costs in the future in response to atrocities, they would reduce the likelihood of mass atrocities. In addition, if diplomatic sanctions damage an abusive leader’s domestic standing, they would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities by helping facilitate a political transition.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Development assistance
Short description: Aid that promotes economic growth, welfare, and humanitarian relief
Description_tool: Development assistance is “government aid that promotes and specifically targets the economic development and welfare of developing countries” (OECD). Development assistance is typically organized into sectors, including democracy, rights, and governance; economic growth; health; education; and humanitarian assistance (USAID). Our research review includes studies of the linkage between development assistance of any or all sectors with mass atrocities or closely related outcomes. As such, it is not a detailed review of alternative program-level interventions. Research reviews of programming options in conflict prevention and peacebuilding can be found from the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation and the United Kingdom’s Department for International Development. Guidance on programming options to help prevent mass atrocities can be found from USAID.
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities
Theory of change: If development assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Security assistance
Short description: Aid that promotes another state’s defense
Description_tool: Security assistance is support provided by a government in the form of “defense articles, military education and training, and other defense-related services to eligible foreign governments by grant, loan, credit, cash sales, or lease” (Office of the Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Army for Defense Exports and Cooperation).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, and (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations.
Theory of change: If security assistance increases the expected benefits of alternative courses of action to committing mass atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities. In addition, if security assistance enables a state to provide physical protection to civilian populations, to increase costs to other armed actors of committing atrocities (e.g., by attacking them in response to atrocities), or to destroy or degrade other groups’ capacities to commit atrocities, it would reduce the likelihood or severity of mass atrocities.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Fact-finding
Short description: Information gathering efforts on conflicts and/or violations of international law
Description_tool: Fact-finding is the acquisition “of detailed knowledge about the factual circumstances of any dispute or situation … which might threaten the maintenance of international peace and security” (UN General Assembly 1991) and/or the investigation of violations of international humanitarian law and international human rights law in an effort “to promote accountability … and counter impunity” (OHCHR 2015, p. 2).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Security guarantees
Short description: Promises made to protect or respect a party’s security
Description_tool: Security guarantees are “any implicit or explicit promise given by an outside power to protect” particular parties to a conflict (Walter 1997, p. 345). They can be “positive,” meaning a promise to come to a party’s aid, or “negative,” meaning a promise to refrain from attack or using specific weapons (Freeman 2003). They are often offered during peace negotiations or mediation efforts to draw parties to the negotiation table or agree to a peace agreement.
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Support to civilian self-protection efforts
Short description: Assistance to help civilian communities protect themselves
Description_tool: Civilian self-protection efforts include “any activities that conflict-affected communities undertake with the intention of countering, mitigating, deterring or avoiding a threat” (Gorur 2013, p. 4). Governments, international organizations, and non-governmental organizations can support these efforts through advice, funding, or the provision of material goods.
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Cyber attacks
Short description: Attacks on computer systems or networks
Description_tool: Cyber attacks are "efforts to alter, disrupt, or destroy computer systems or networks or the information or programs on them" (Waxman 2011, p. 422).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Public diplomacy
Description_tool: Public diplomacy involves the ways “a sovereign country communicates with publics in other countries aimed at informing and influencing audiences overseas for the purpose of promoting the national interest and advancing its foreign policy goals” (USC Center on Public Diplomacy). Examples include “educational exchange programs for scholars and students; visitor programs; language training; cultural events and exchanges; and radio and television broadcasting” (USC Center on Public Diplomacy).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (4) facilitating a political transition.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Bilateral diplomacy
Short description: Diplomatic relations and activity between two countries
Description_tool: Bilateral diplomacy consists of “the state-to-state process” by which a state “engages individual foreign states, across a spectrum of subjects, to advance one’s own domestic and international objectives” (Rana 2020, pp. 2, 4). Bilateral diplomacy may include correspondence and agreements between diplomatic missions of the host state and sending country.
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations, and (4) facilitating a political transition.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Multilateral diplomacy
Short description: Diplomatic relations between multiple states or through international institutions
Description_tool: Multilateral diplomacy is “the practice of involving more than two nations or parties in achieving diplomatic solutions to supranational problems” (Mahbubani 2013). It includes engagement with ad hoc groupings of countries and diplomacy through formal international organizations, such as the United Nations, NATO, and the Organization of American States.
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities, (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations, and (4) facilitating a political transition.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Military presence
Short description: Non-invasion, peacetime troops stationed in a host state
Description_tool: Military presence includes the “peacetime presence of a foreign military on the territory of another sovereign state without interference into the host’s domestic authority structures” (Schmidt 2014, pp. 817-818) with the consent of the host state (Martinez Machain and Morgan 2013, p. 102).
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (3) protecting vulnerable civilian populations.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Refugee protection
Short description: The legal and physical protection of refugees
Description_tool: Refugee protection can include many specific actions to provide legal and physical protection to people who have fled their home country for fear of persecution (UNHCR USA). In addition to immediate life-saving assistance, refugee protection involves facilitating one of three “durable solutions” - voluntary repatriation, local integration, or resettlement in a third country (UNHCR 2016, pp. 180-181).
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Trade or investment incentives
Short description: Economic measures that seek to incentivize specific state behavior
Description_tool: Trade or investment incentives include policies that seek to encourage or discourage state behavior by linking it with potential economic benefits. Such policies might consist of conditional offers of debt relief, exchange rate adjustment, and preferential trade agreements.
Strategies the tool can support: (1) dissuading potential perpetrators from committing atrocities, and (2) degrading potential perpetrators’ capacity to commit atrocities.
Description: NA
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Democracy
Description: The country under study is a democracy. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with autocracy or authoritarian regime type can be considered equivalent to findings associated with the absence of democracy.)
Inverse factor description: The country under study is an autocracy or authoritarian regime.

Name: Anocracy or hybrid regime
Description: The country under study is an anocracy or hybrid regime.
Inverse factor description: The country under study is not an anocracy or hybrid regime.

Name: Rebel control of territory
Description: The territory where mass atrocities are occurring is controlled or governed by a rebel group.
Inverse factor description: The territory where mass atrocities are occurring is not controlled or governed by a rebel group.

Name: Military regime
Description: The country under study is ruled by a military regime.
Inverse factor description: The country under study is not ruled by a military regime.

Name: Difficult terrain
Description: The territory is mountainous or has terrain that is difficult to navigate.
Inverse factor description: The territory is not mountainous or has terrain that is easy to navigate.

Name: Domestic punishment likely
Description: Punishment for the perpetrators of mass atrocities is likely in the domestic context.
Inverse factor description: Punishment for the perpetrators of mass atrocities is unlikely in the domestic context.

Name: History of tool use
Description: The tool has been used in the country’s history.
Inverse factor description: The tool has not been used in the country’s history.

Name: Domestic cooperation or consent with the tool
Description: The country under study cooperates with the tool.
Inverse factor: No domestic cooperation with the tool
Inverse factor description: The country under study does not cooperate with the tool or the tool implementer.

Name: Highly developed state
Description: The country under study is highly developed.
Inverse factor description: The country under study is not highly developed.

Name: Local support for tool
Description: Most of the local population and/or local civil society supports the use of the tool and perceives its use as legitimate.
Inverse factor description: There is a low degree of local population support or civil society mobilization for the use or goals of the tool, and/or the local population perceives the use of the tool as illegitimate.

Name: National atrocity prevention efforts
Description: The government of the country under study is concurrently taking other actions to help prevent mass atrocities.
Inverse factor description: The government of the country under study is not implementing other tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.

Name: Domestic justice or human rights infrastructure
Dedoose name: Domestic justice or human rights infrastructure
Description: The country under study has a well-developed domestic justice infrastructure, has many human rights organizations, and/or has ratified international human rights treaties.
Inverse factor: Limited domestic justice or human rights infrastructure
Inverse factor description: The country under study (1) has a poorly-developed domestic justice infrastructure; (2) has few human rights organizations; or (3) has not ratified key human rights treaties.

Name: Ripeness
Description: The parties to the conflict perceive a negotiated resolution as in their mutual interest.
Inverse factor: The conflict is not ripe for resolution.
Inverse factor description: The parties to the conflict do not perceive a negotiated resolution as in their mutual interest.

Name: War weariness
Description: There is a feeling of exhaustion or disillusion caused by a prolonged conflict in the territory in which mass atrocities are occurring.
Inverse factor description: There is no feeling of exhaustion or disillusion caused by prolonged conflict in the territory in which mass atrocities are occurring.

Name: Nationalist political leverage
Description: Nationalists have significant political leverage in the country under study.
Inverse factor description: Nationalists have limited political leverage in the country under study.

Name: High ethnic diversity
Description: The country under study has a high degree of ethnic diversity.
Inverse factor description: The country under study has a low degree of ethnic diversity.

Name: Ethnic exclusion or polarization
Description: The state where mass atrocities are occurring is characterized by high levels of ethnic exclusion or ethnic polarization.
Inverse factor description: The country under study is characterized by low levels of ethnic exclusion or ethnic polarization.

Name: High-risk state
Description: The country under study exhibits a combination of characteristics that increase the likelihood of conflict onset, such as low GDP per capita and rule by anocracy.
Inverse factor description: The country under study does not exhibit characteristics that increase the likelihood of conflict onset.

Name: Conventional tactics
Description: Parties to the conflict use conventional tactics, which include well-defined forces on each side and the use of conventional weapons.
Inverse factor description: Parties to the conflict do not use conventional tactics, which include well-defined forces on each side and the use of conventional weapons.

Name: Guerrilla warfare
Description: Parties to the conflict use guerrilla warfare, in which small groups of combatants target a larger military through ambushes, raids, etc.
Inverse factor description: Parties to the conflict do not use guerrilla warfare, in which small groups of combatants target a larger military through ambushes, raids, etc.

Name: History of compromise
Description: There is a history of compromise or a high degree of trust between conflict parties.
Inverse factor description: There is no history of compromise or a low degree of trust between conflict parties.

Name: History of conflict
Description: The parties to the conflict or the country under study has a history of violent conflict.
Inverse factor description: Neither the parties to the conflict nor the country under study has a history of violent conflict.

Name: Comprehensive settlement or peace agreement
Description: There is a comprehensive settlement or peace agreement between the conflict parties.
Inverse factor: No comprehensive settlement or peace agreement
Inverse factor description: There is no comprehensive settlement or peace agreement between the conflict parties.

Name: Government principally responsible for atrocities
Description: The government is principally responsible for atrocities, human rights abuses, or one-sided violence.
Inverse factor: Government not principally responsible for atrocities
Inverse factor description: The government is not principally responsible for atrocities, human rights abuses, or one-sided violence.

Name: Non-state armed groups principally responsible for atrocities
Description: Non-state armed groups are principally responsible for atrocities, human rights abuses, or one-sided violence.
Inverse factor: Non-state armed groups not principally responsible for atrocities
Inverse factor description: Non-state armed groups are not principally responsible for atrocities, human rights abuses, or one-sided violence.

Name: Atrocities by the government and non-state armed groups
Description: Atrocities, human rights abuses, or one-sided violence are being perpetrated by the government and non-state armed groups.
Inverse factor: Atrocities not by both government and non-state armed groups
Inverse factor description: Atrocities, human rights abuses, or one-sided violence are not being perpetrated by both the government and non-state armed groups.

Name: Conflict between multiple states
Description: The conflict that the country is experiencing is between the government and the government of another country.
Inverse factor description: The conflict that the country is experiencing is not between the government and the government of another country.

Name: Conflict between the government and a non-state actor
Description: The conflict that the country is experiencing is between a government and a non-state group within the country.
Inverse factor description: The conflict that the country is experiencing is not between a government and a non-state group within the country.

Name: Secessionist conflict
Description: The country is experiencing a conflict that concerns a party’s effort to establish an independent state on part of the territory claimed by a state.
Inverse factor description: The country is not experiencing a conflict that concerns a party’s effort to establish an independent state on part of the territory claimed by a state.

Name: Identity-based conflict
Description: The country is experiencing a conflict that concerns the rights or territory of an ethnic, religious, racial, and/or other identity group.
Inverse factor description: The country is not experiencing a conflict that concerns the rights or territory of an ethnic, religious, racial, and/or other identity group.

Name: Military victory
Description: The country experienced a conflict that ended in a military victory.
Inverse factor description: The country did not experience a conflict that ended in a military victory.

Name: Ongoing armed conflict
Description: There is an ongoing armed conflict in the country under study.
Inverse factor description: There is no ongoing armed conflict in the country under study.

Name: External assistance or foreign troops
Description: There are foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation or external actors are offering assistance to the conflict parties.
Inverse factor: Absence of external assistance or foreign troops
Inverse factor description: There are no foreign troops active in the ongoing conflict situation nor are external actors offering assistance to the conflict parties.

Name: More than two conflict parties
Description: The country is experiencing a conflict consisting of more than two parties.
Inverse factor description: There are two parties to the conflict.

Name: Long conflict
Description: The country is experiencing a conflict of long duration.
Inverse factor description: The country is experiencing a conflict of short duration.

Name: High intensity conflict
Description: The country is experiencing a conflict characterized by high-intensity fighting or a high death toll.
Inverse factor description: The country is experiencing a conflict characterized by low-intensity fighting or a low death toll.

Name: Safe haven for perpetrator
Description: Perpetrator(s) of mass atrocities very likely have access to territory where they would be shielded from the tool's effects.
Inverse factor description: There is a low likelihood that the perpetrator of mass atrocities has access to territory that shields them from the tool's effects.

Name: Strong spoiler groups
Description: There are powerful groups that have the desire and capacity to disrupt or damage peace initiatives in the country under study.
Inverse factor description: There are no powerful vested interests, warring parties, third party actors or "spoilers" who have the desire and capacity to spoil peace outcomes in the country under study.

Name: Strong government
Description: The national government is strong, or has a high degree of resilience, adaptability, military experience, power, or territorial control.
Inverse factor description: The government in the conflict is weak or has a low degree of resilience, adaptability, military experience, power, or territorial control.

Name: Strong non-state armed group
Description: Non-state armed group(s) are strong or have a high degree of resilience, adaptability, military experience, power, or territorial control.
Inverse factor description: The non-state armed group in the conflict is weak and has a low degree of resilience, adaptability, military experience, power, or territorial control.

Name: Balance of power or stalemate
Description: The national government and non-state armed group(s) have similar levels of resilience, adaptability, military experience, power, or territorial control.
Inverse factor description: The national government and non-state armed group(s) do not have similar levels of resilience, adaptability, military experience, power, or territorial control.

Name: Existence of a peace agreement involving amnesties
Description: There is a peace agreement involving amnesties.
Inverse factor: Absence of a peace agreement involving amnesties
Inverse factor description: There is no peace agreement involving amnesties in the conflict.

Name: Cohesive conflict parties
Description: The conflict parties are internally unified.
Inverse factor description: The conflict parties are splintered.

Name: Imbalance of wealth between conflict parties
Description: There is an imbalance of wealth between conflict parties.
Inverse factor: Balance of wealth between conflict parties
Inverse factor description: There is a balance of wealth between conflict parties.

Name: Regional use of tool
Description: The tool is being implemented by neighboring countries or a regional organization.
Inverse factor: Absence of regional use of the tool
Inverse factor description: The tool is not being implemented by neighboring countries or a regional organization.

Name: International support or coordination
Description: There is a high degree of international support for the use of the tool, or the tool implementer coordinates with other international actors on the use of the tool.
Inverse factor: Lack of international support or coordination
Inverse factor description: There is a low degree of international support for the use of the tool, or the tool implementer does not coordinate with other international actors on the use of the tool.

Name: Ideologically motivated target
Description: The target is motivated by atrocity-justifying ideology or revenge.
Inverse factor: Absence of atrocity-justifying ideology or revenge
Inverse factor description: The target is not motivated by atrocity-justifying ideology or revenge.

Name: Rational target
Description: The target is a rational actor.
Inverse factor description: The target is an irrational actor.

Name: High status target
Description: The target is a top leader or has high status.
Inverse factor: Not a top leader or high status
Inverse factor description: The target is not a top leader or has low status.

Name: Tool targets foot soldiers and leaders
Description: The tool targets foot soldiers as well as leaders.
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Large number of targets
Description: The tool targets a large number of individuals.
Inverse factor description: The tool targets a small number of individuals

Name: Aid-dependent target
Description: The target is dependent on foreign aid.
Inverse factor description: The target is not dependent on foreign aid.

Name: Target prioritizes reputation
Description: The target cares about their reputation among domestic and international audiences.
Inverse factor description: The target does not care about their reputation among domestic and international audiences.

Name: Risk-tolerant target
Description: The target is risk-tolerant.
Inverse factor description: The target is risk-intolerant.

Name: State target
Description: The target is a state actor or state group.
Inverse factor description: The target is a non-state actor or non-state group.

Name: Hierarchical target
Description: The target is a group with a clearly established leadership hierarchy.
Inverse factor description: The target is a group without a clearly established leadership hierarchy.

Name: Established target
Description: The target is a well-established or old group.
Inverse factor description: The target is a poorly-established or new group.

Name: Popular target
Description: The target has popular support.
Inverse factor description: The target lacks popular support.

Name: Religious target
Description: The target is a religious individual or group.
Inverse factor description: The target is a non-religious individual or group.

Name: Transnational target
Description: The target operates transnationally.
Inverse factor description: The target does not operate transnationally.

Name: Target has access to resources
Description: The target has access to resources, such as oil or gemstones.
Inverse factor description: The target lacks access to resources, such as oil or gemstones, to continue the conflict.

Name: Target relies on international trade and investment
Dedoose name: Reliance on international trade and investment
Description: The target relies on international trade or investment.
Inverse factor: Target does not rely on international trade or investment
Inverse factor description: The target does not rely on international trade or investment

Name: Target is a terror group
Description: The target is a terror group.
Inverse factor: Target is not a terror group
Inverse factor description: The target is not a terror group.

Name: Target is a severe human rights violator
Description: The target has committed an extensive number of human rights violations in the conflict in which mass atrocities or closely-related outcomes are occurring.
Inverse factor: Target is not a severe human rights violator
Inverse factor description: The target has committed a less extensive number of human rights violations in the conflict in which mass atrocities or closely-related outcomes are occurring.

Name: Target rebel group has a political wing
Description: The target rebel group has a political wing.
Inverse factor: The target rebel group does not have a political wing
Inverse factor description: The target rebel group does not have a political wing.

Name: Member of the implementing institution
Description: The target is a member of the implementing institution.
Inverse factor description: The target is not a member of the implementing institution.

Name: Conflict parties
Description: The target is an active party to the conflict.
Inverse factor description: The target is not an active party to the conflict.

Name: Corrupt
Description: The target engages in corrupt activities.
Inverse factor description: The target does not engage in corrupt activities.

Name: Moderate policy goal
Description: The tool implementer has a moderate policy objective.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer has immoderate or extreme policy objectives.

Name: Conflict parties share organizational membership
Description: The conflict parties are members of the same regional or international organization.
Inverse factor: Conflict parties do not share organizational membership
Inverse factor description: The conflict parties are not members of the same regional or international organization.

Name: Target leadership change
Description: The target experiences leadership change during the tool's use.
Inverse factor description: The target experiences consistent leadership during the tool's use.

Name: Civilian implementer
Description: The tool implementer is civilian.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is non-civilian.

Name: Non-governmental implementer
Description: The tool implementer is a non-governmental organization.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is not a non-governmental organization.

Name: State implementer
Description: The tool implementer is a foreign government.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is not a foreign government.

Name: Media implementer
Description: The tool implementer is a media organization.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is not a media organization.

Name: International organization implementer
Description: The tool implementer is an international governmental organization.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is not an international governmental organization.

Name: Adversary implementer
Description: The tool implementer is an adversary or geopolitical rival of the target.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is not an adversary or geopolitical rival of the target.

Name: Diaspora implementer
Description: The tool implementer is members of the diaspora.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is not members of the diaspora.

Name: Neighbor implementer
Description: The target and the tool implementer are in the same region or members of the same regional organization.
Inverse factor description: The target and the tool implementer are not in the same region or members of the same regional organization.

Name: Western implementer
Description: The tool implementer is Western.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is not Western.

Name: Domestic implementer
Description: The tool implementer is domestic, i.e., from the target state.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is foreign, i.e., not from the target state.

Name: Well-informed implementer
Description: The tool implementer is well-versed in the political and social context in which the conflict is occurring, or has credible information about the intentions or capabilities of the target.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is poorly-versed in the political and social context in which the conflict is occurring, or lacks credible information about the intentions or capabilities of the target.

Name: Experienced implementer
Description: The tool implementer was previously involved in efforts to use the tool in the conflict in which mass atrocities are occurring.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer was not previously involved in efforts to use the tool in the conflict in which mass atrocities are occurring.

Name: Skilled implementer
Description: The tool implementer is highly competent in the use of the tool.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is incompetent in the use of the tool.

Name: Democratic implementer
Description: The tool implementer is a democracy.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is not a democracy.

Name: Multiple competitive implementers
Description: There are multiple tool implementers in competition with each other.
Inverse factor description: There are not multiple tool implementers in competition with each other.

Name: Implementer has clear command and control
Description: The tool implementer has clear command and control structures that are adhered to.
Inverse factor: Implementer does not have clear command and control
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer does not have clear command and control structures that are adhered to.

Name: Unrealistic expectations
Description: The implementer sets unrealistic expectations for the target’s behavior.
Inverse factor description: The implementer does not set unrealistic expectations for the target’s behavior.

Name: Implementer has strong leadership
Description: The tool implementer has strong leadership.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer has weak leadership

Name: Implementer has strong human rights record
Description: The tool implementer has a strong human rights record or record of protecting civilians.
Inverse factor: Implementer has weak human rights record
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer has a weak human rights record or does not have a record of protecting civilians.

Name: Committed implementer
Description: The tool implementer has a high level of commitment, resolve, or credibility, or has committed a great deal of resources toward use of the tool.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer has a low level of commitment, resolve, or credibility, or has committed few resources toward use of the tool.

Name: Implementer has strong leverage
Description: The tool implementer (1) has a significant degree of relative power in the international system, (2) is a member of the “Permanent Five" (P5) countries on the UN Security Council, or (3) has significant leverage over the conflict parties.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer (1) has a low degree of relative power in the international system, (2) is not a member of the “Permanent Five” (P5) countries on the UN Security Council, or (3) has weak leverage over the conflict parties

Name: Implementer-target colonial history
Description: The tool implementer has colonial history with the target.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer does not have colonial history with the target.

Name: Implementer-target similar legal systems
Description: The tool implementer and target have similar legal systems.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer and target have different legal systems.

Name: Implementer-target diplomatic ties
Description: The tool implementer has diplomatic ties with the target.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer does not have diplomatic ties with the target.

Name: Cohesive implementer
Description: The tool implementer has a cohesive agenda.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer has a splintered agenda.

Name: Motivated by great power competition
Description: The tool implementer is motivated by great power competition.
Inverse factor: Not motivated by great power competition
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is not motivated by great power competition.

Name: Public communication
Description: The use of the tool is communicated or publicized widely.
Inverse factor description: The use of the tool is not communicated or publicized widely.

Name: Private communication to target
Description: The use of the tool is communicated privately to the target.
Inverse factor: Absence of private communication to target
Inverse factor description: The use of the tool is not communicated privately to the target.

Name: Early implementation
Description: The tool is implemented early in the conflict or rapidly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.
Inverse factor description: The tool is implemented late in the conflict or slowly after the appearance of early warning signs or occurrence of mass atrocities.

Name: Consistent implementation
Description: The tool is implemented consistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.
Inverse factor description: The tool is implemented inconsistently over time and across parties/perpetrator groups.

Name: Multiple implementations
Description: The tool is implemented multiple times in one conflict episode.
Inverse factor description: The tool is implemented only once in a conflict episode.

Name: Monitoring and adjustment
Description: The success of the tool is monitored and the tool is adjusted to maximize success.
Inverse factor description: The success of the tool is not monitored nor is the tool adjusted to maximize success.

Name: Flexibility and linkage to behavior
Description: The use of the tool is flexible and linked to the behavior of the target--i.e., if the target improves their behavior, the tool is lifted.
Inverse factor: Inflexibility and no linkage to behavior
Inverse factor description: The use of the tool is inflexible and not linked to the behavior of the target--i.e., if the target improves their behavior, the tool is not lifted.

Name: Biased implementer or intervention
Description: The tool implementer or intervention is biased toward one party. Bias refers to the posture of the intervener, not necessarily prejudices that the intervener might hold about parties.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer or intervention is not biased toward either party. Bias refers to the posture of the intervener, not necessarily prejudices that the intervener might hold about parties.

Name: Concurrent use of multiple tools
Description: The tool implementer or other actors are simultaneously implementing other tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.
Inverse factor description: No actors are implementing tools that are consistent with the goals of the tool.

Name: Local outreach
Description: The tool implementer makes efforts to reach out to local communities or the host government to build better relationships.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer makes no efforts to reach out to local communities or the host government to build better relationships.

Name: Threat of use of tool
Description: The tool implementer threatens the use of the tool.
Inverse factor: No threat of use of tool
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer does not threaten the use of the tool.

Name: Clear policy objectives
Description: The implementer's objectives in using the tool are clear.
Inverse factor description: The implementer's objectives in using the tool are unclear.

Name: Limited scope
Description: The tool is applied in a limited way or targets a limited set of issues within the conflict.
Inverse factor description: The tool targets a broad set of issues within the conflict.

Name: Tool addresses internal and external issues
Description: The tool addresses internal and external issues together.
Inverse factor: Tool addresses internal or external issues
Inverse factor description: The tool addresses either internal or external issues, not both.

Name: Tool addresses root causes
Description: The tool addresses the root causes of the conflict.
Inverse factor: Tool does not address root causes
Inverse factor description: The tool does not address the root causes of the conflict.

Name: Tool targets leader family members
Description: The tool targets the leader’s family members.
Inverse factor: Tool does not target leader family members
Inverse factor description: The tool does not target the leader’s family members.

Name: Conditionalities
Description: The tool implementer imposes specific conditions that the recipient must adhere to in order to receive the assistance.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer does not impose specific conditions that the recipient must adhere to in order to receive the assistance.

Name: Official mediation
Description: The mediation is track 1 or official diplomacy. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with track 2, 1.5, or unofficial mediation can be considered equivalent to findings associated with non-official mediation.)
Inverse factor description: The mediation is track 2 or 1.5 or unofficial diplomacy.

Name: Multiple types of mediation
Description: Official mediation efforts are occurring simultaneously with unofficial mediation efforts.
Inverse factor description: Official mediation efforts are not occurring simultaneously with unofficial mediation efforts.

Name: Decisive mediation strategy
Description: The mediator deploys a decisive strategy.
Inverse factor description: The mediator deploys an indecisive strategy.

Name: Indirect mediation
Description: The mediation effort is indirect.
Inverse factor description: The mediation effort is direct.

Name: Sequenced mediation
Description: The mediation takes a sequenced approach.
Inverse factor description: The mediation takes a non-sequenced approach.

Name: Directive mediation
Description: The mediation uses a directive strategy (sometimes also referred to as “manipulative”).
Inverse factor description: The mediation uses a non-directive strategy.

Name: Conflict party initiates mediation
Description: The mediation is initiated by one of the parties to the conflict in which mass atrocities are occurring, rather than a third-party actor.
Inverse factor description: The mediation is initiated by a third party actor, rather than one of the parties to the conflict in which mass atrocities are occurring.

Name: Mediation excludes spoilers
Description: Spoiler groups are excluded from the mediation coalition.
Inverse factor description: Spoiler groups are included in the mediation coalition.

Name: Mediation includes diverse actors
Description: The mediation includes diverse actors.
Inverse factor description: The mediation excludes diverse actors.

Name: Multiple mediators
Description: There are multiple mediators mediating the conflict.
Inverse factor description: There is a single mediator mediating the conflict.

Name: Change of mediator
Description: The mediator changes during the course of the mediation.
Inverse factor description: The mediator is consistent throughout the course of the mediation.

Name: Neutral venue for mediation
Description: The mediation is held in a neutral venue.
Inverse factor description: The mediation is held in a biased venue.

Name: Mediation includes all conflict parties
Description: The mediation includes all conflict parties.
Inverse factor: Mediation does not include all conflict parties
Inverse factor description: The mediation does not include all conflict parties.

Name: Initiating investigation
Description: An investigation has been initiated.
Inverse factor description: An investigation has not been initiated.

Name: Investigations transferred to pre-trial chamber
Description: Investigations have been transferred to a pre-trial chamber.
Inverse factor: Investigations not transferred to a pre-trial chamber
Inverse factor description: Investigations have not been transferred to a pre-trial chamber.

Name: Preliminary examination
Description: A preliminary examination has occurred.
Inverse factor description: No preliminary examination has occurred.

Name: Request for arrest warrant
Description: There has been a request for an arrest warrant.
Inverse factor: No request for an arrest warrant
Inverse factor description: There has been no request for an arrest warrant.

Name: Arrest warrant
Description: An arrest warrant has been issued.
Inverse factor description: An arrest warrant has not been issued.

Name: Indictment
Description: There has been an indictment.
Inverse factor description: There has not been an indictment.

Name: Conviction or severe punishment
Description: The prosecution resulted in conviction or severe punishment.
Inverse factor: Absence of conviction or severe punishment
Inverse factor description: The prosecution did not result in conviction or severe punishment.

Name: Domestic prosecution
Description: The prosecution is driven by a domestic court system.
Inverse factor description: The prosecution is not driven by a domestic court system.

Name: International prosecution
Description: The prosecution is driven by an international body.
Inverse factor description: The prosecution is not driven by an international body.

Name: Prosecution occurs after negotiated settlement
Description: The prosecution occurs after a negotiated settlement.
Inverse factor: Prosecution does not occur after negotiated settlement
Inverse factor description: The prosecution does not occur after a negotiated settlement.

Name: Witness protection
Description: The prosecution effectively protects witnesses and victims.
Inverse factor description: The prosecution does not effectively protect witnesses and victims.

Name: Target aware of international justice system
Dedoose name: Perp_awareness of the international justice system
Description: The target is familiar with the basic procedures and processes of the international criminal justice system.
Inverse factor: Target unaware of international justice system
Inverse factor description: The target is familiar with the basic procedures and processes of the international criminal justice system

Name: UN Security Council referral
Description: The case being prosecuted was referred to the International Criminal Court by the UN Security Council.
Inverse factor: Absence of UN Security Council referral
Inverse factor description: The case being prosecuted was not referred to the International Criminal Court by the UN Security Council.

Name: Conflict parties prefer domestic justice
Description: Conflict parties prefer domestic transitional justice to ICC justice.
Inverse factor: Conflict parties do not prefer domestic justice
Inverse factor description: Conflict parties do not prefer domestic transitional justice to ICC justice.

Name: Provision of troops
Description: The tool implementer provides troops to the non-state armed group.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer does not provide troops to the non-state armed group.

Name: Provision of money or arms
Description: The tool implementer provides money or arms to the non-state armed group.
Inverse factor: No provision of money or arms
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer does not provide money or arms to the non-state armed group.

Name: Provision of safe haven
Description: The tool implementer provides safe haven to the non-state armed group.
Inverse factor: No provision of rebel safe haven
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer does not provide safe haven to the non-state armed group.

Name: High quantity of support
Description: The quantity of external support to the state actor or non-state armed group results in a large increase in the group’s capabilities.
Inverse factor description: The quantity of external support to the state actor or non-state armed group does not result in a large increase in the group’s capabilities.

Name: Conflict termination goals
Description: The tool implementer’s policy objective is to end the civil war or conflict.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer’s policy objective is not to end the civil war or conflict.

Name: Observer mission
Description: The peace operation is an observer mission or has a traditional mandate that includes principles of consent, neutrality, or minimal use of force.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation is not an observer mission nor does it have a traditional mandate that includes principles of consent, neutrality, or minimal use of force.

Name: Protection of civilians mandate
Description: The peace operation has a mandate to protect civilians.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation does not have a mandate to protect civilians.

Name: Multidimensional mandate
Description: The peace operation has a mandate that is described as multidimensional, transformational, robust, or centered on enforcement or stabilization goals. These mandates include the use of force by peacekeepers for purposes other than the explicit protection of civilians.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation does not have a mandate that is described as multidimensional, transformational, robust, or centered on enforcement or stabilization goals. These mandates include the use of force by peacekeepers for purposes other than the explicit protection of civilians.

Name: Humanitarian mission
Description: The peace operation has a humanitarian purpose which can include protecting humanitarian convoys, humanitarian operations, and/or humanitarian aid.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation does not have a humanitarian purpose which can include protecting humanitarian convoys, humanitarian operations, and/or humanitarian aid.

Name: DDR mandate
Description: The peace operation has a disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration mandate.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation does not have a disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration mandate.

Name: UN mandate
Description: The peacekeeping mission is operating under a UN mandate. (Note - For our review, we assume that findings associated with a regional mandate can be considered equivalent to findings associated with a non-UN mandate.)
Inverse factor description: The peacekeeping mission is operating under a regional mandate.

Name: Willingness/ability to use force
Description: The tool implementer is willing and able to use force.
Inverse factor: Absence of willingness/ability to use force
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer is unwilling or unable to use force.

Name: Diverse troop-contributing countries
Description: The peace operation is comprised of troops from a diverse set of countries.
Inverse factor description: NA

Name: Election engagement
Description: The peace operation is engaged in election-related activities.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation is not engaged in election-related activities.

Name: Use of troops
Description: The peace operation is comprised of military troops.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation is not comprised of military troops.

Name: Use of safe areas
Description: The peace operation uses safe areas.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation does not use safe areas.

Name: Consent
Description: The peace operation has secured broad consent.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation has not secured broad consent

Name: Use of private contractors/companies
Description: The peace operation deploys private security contractors or companies.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation does not deploy private security contractors or companies.

Name: Civilian component
Description: The peace operation has a large civilian component.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation does not have a large civilian component.

Name: Ability to separate combatants
Description: The peace operation is able to separate combatants from civilians.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation is unable to separate combatants from civilians.

Name: High quantity of troops
Description: The peacekeeping or intervening military force is large in size.
Inverse factor: Small peacekeeping or intervening military force
Inverse factor description: The peacekeeping or intervening military force is small in size.

Name: Police
Description: The peace operation has police.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation does not have police.

Name: Non-politicized naming and shaming
Description: The naming and shaming is technical.
Inverse factor description: The naming and shaming is politicized.

Name: Multiple types of sanctions
Description: The tool implementer implements multiple types of targeted sanctions.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer implements a single type of targeted sanctions.

Name: High economic cost
Description: The comprehensive economic sanctions impose a high economic cost on the target.
Inverse factor description: The comprehensive economic sanctions impose a low economic cost on the target.

Name: Legal lootable resources
Description: The country is experiencing a conflict that involves legal lootable resources.
Inverse factor description: The country is experiencing a conflict that does not involve legal lootable resources.

Name: Target pays implementer with resource concessions
Description: The target pays the tool implementer with resource concessions.
Inverse factor: Target does not pay implementer with resource concessions
Inverse factor description: The target does not pay the tool implementer with resource concessions.

Name: Pro-government intervention
Description: The military intervention is conducted in support of the government in the country under study.
Inverse factor description: The military intervention is not conducted in support of the government in the country under study.

Name: Pro-rebel intervention
Description: The military intervention is conducted in support of the rebel group(s) in the country under study.
Inverse factor description: The military intervention is not conducted in support of the rebel group(s) in the country under study.

Name: Anti-perpetrator intervention
Description: The military intervention is conducted in opposition to the perpetrator of violence in the country under study.
Inverse factor description: The military intervention is not conducted in opposition to the perpetrator of violence in the country under study.

Name: Neutral intervention
Description: The military intervention is not conducted in support of a particular conflict party in the country under study.
Inverse factor description: The military intervention is conducted in support of a particular conflict party in the country under study.

Name: Non-lootable resources
Description: The country under study is experiencing a conflict that involves non-lootable resources, such as off-shore oil.
Inverse factor description: The country under study is experiencing a conflict that does not involve non-lootable resources, such as off-shore oil.

Name: Strategy targets civilians
Description: The military intervention targets civilians.
Inverse factor description: The military intervention does not target civilians.

Name: Airpower
Description: The military intervention uses airpower.
Inverse factor description: The military intervention does not use airpower.

Name: Implementer demands regime change
Description: The tool implementer demands regime change in the country under study.
Inverse factor: Implementer does not demand regime change
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer does not demand regime change in the country under study.

Name: Counter-terrorism objective
Description: The tool has a counter-terrorism policy objective.
Inverse factor description: The tool does not have a counter-terrorism policy objective.

Name: Democratization mandate
Description: The tool has a democratization mandate or policy objective.
Inverse factor description: The tool does not have a democratization mandate or policy objective.

Name: Independent agenda
Description: The tool implementer pursues an agenda independent of conflict parties' agendas.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer pursues an agenda that aligns with at least one of the conflict parties’ agendas.

Name: Strategic interest
Description: The tool implementer has a strategic interest in the country under study, such as an economic, security, or broader interest.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer has no strategic interest in the country under study.

Name: Leaders do not join amnesty
Description: The leaders of the country or rebel group under study do not participate in the amnesty.
Inverse factor description: The leaders of the country or rebel group under study participate in the amnesty.

Name: Large money transfers
Description: The amnesty agreement involves the transfer of large sums of money to the individuals that the amnesty covers.
Inverse factor description: The amnesty agreement does not involve the transfer of large sums of money to the individuals that the amnesty covers.

Name: Amnesty for serious human rights violations
Description: The amnesty agreement covers serious human rights violations.
Inverse factor: No amnesty for serious human rights violations
Inverse factor description: The amnesty agreement does not cover serious human rights violations.

Name: Limited amnesty timespan
Description: The amnesty covers acts that took place during a limited timespan.
Inverse factor description: The amnesty covers acts that took place during a broad timespan.

Name: Amnesty includes relevant parties
Description: The amnesty agreement includes relevant parties to the conflict.
Inverse factor: Amnesty does not include relevant parties
Inverse factor description: The amnesty agreement does not include relevant parties to the conflict.

Name: Awareness of tool
Description: The target is aware that the tool is being implemented.
Inverse factor description: The target is not aware that the tool is being implemented

Name: Promise of use of the tool
Description: The tool implementer promises to use the tool.
Inverse factor description: The tool implementer does not promise to use the tool.

Name: Concentrated or inequitable disbursement
Description: The assistance is concentrated with a select number of elites or is inequitably disbursed.
Inverse factor description: The assistance is not concentrated with a select number of elites or is equitably disbursed.

Name: Economic shock
Description: The country under study has recently experienced an economic shock.
Inverse factor description: The country under study has not recently experienced an economic shock.

Name: Inflation
Description: The economy of the country under study is experiencing inflation.
Inverse factor description: The economy of the country under study is not experiencing inflation.

Name: Neighboring state support
Description: Countries nearby support the leadership of the country under study.
Inverse factor description: Countries nearby do not support the leadership of the country under study.

Name: Cash-based assistance
Description: The development assistance involves the transfer of unrestricted funds or is described as fungible.
Inverse factor description: The development assistance does not involve the transfer of unrestricted funds or is described as fungible.

Name: Humanitarian aid
Description: The purpose of the assistance is humanitarian.
Inverse factor description: The purpose of the assistance is not humanitarian.

Name: Strong civil society
Description: The country under study has a strong civil society.
Inverse factor description: The country under study has a weak civil society.

Name: Large number of external sponsors
Description: A large number of external actors provide support for non-state armed groups.
Inverse factor description: Few or no external actors provide support for non-state armed groups.
Family: Support to non-state armed groups factors

Name: International exposure of the target
Description: The target has ties to the international financial system and/or family living abroad.
Inverse factor description: The target lacks ties to the international financial system.

Name: Accountability and enforcement mechanism
Description: The use of the tool includes an accountability and enforcement mechanism.
Inverse factor description: The use of the tool lacks an accountability or enforcement mechanism.

Name: Education assistance
Description: The development assistance supports education efforts.
Inverse factor description: The development assistance does not support education efforts.

Name: Human rights objectives
Description: The implementer has a human rights, peacebuilding, or atrocity prevention objective.
Inverse factor description: The implementer does not have a human rights, peacebuilding, or atrocity prevention objective.

Name: Visible human rights abuses
Description: The target commits human rights abuses that are visible to domestic or international audiences.
Inverse factor description: The target commits human rights abuses that are not visible to domestic or international audiences.

Name: Implementer aims to degrade or constrain perpetrators
Description: The implementer uses the tool to degrade or constrain the capacity of potential perpetrators.
Inverse factor: Implementer does not aim to degrade or constrain perpetrators
Inverse factor description: The implementer does not use the tool to degrade or constrain the capacity of potential perpetrators.

Name: Multiple types of development assistance
Description: The implementer uses multiple types of development assistance.
Inverse factor description: The implementer only uses one type of development assistance.

Name: Humanitarian exemptions
Description: The targeted sanctions exempt humanitarian operations from restrictions on trade or financial exchanges.
Inverse factor description: The targeted sanctions do not include humanitarian exemptions.

Name: Multiple specialized units
Description: The peace operations include multiple specialized units.
Inverse factor description: The peace operations do not include multiple specialized units.

Name: Peacekeepers involved in mediation
Description: Peacekeepers are involved in the mediation effort.
Inverse factor description: Peacekeepers are not involved in the mediation effort.

Name: Use of women peacekeepers
Description: The peace operation includes a relatively large percentage of women peacekeepers.
Inverse factor description: The peace operation includes a relatively large percentage of women peacekeepers.

Name: Governance assistance
Description: The development assistance supports governance efforts.
Inverse factor description: The development assistance does not support governance efforts.
